title: 106_s1898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Interstate Transportation of Dangerous Criminals Act of 2000" or "Jeanna's Act." Congress finds that States are increasingly using private prisoner transport companies for violent prisoners, leading to escapes and the need for oversight by the Attorney General. Private prisoner transport companies are used for violent prisoners across the country, leading to escapes. Oversight by the Attorney General is necessary to address these issues. While most prefer using law enforcement officers, fiscal or logistical concerns may prompt the use of specialized private transport companies. While law enforcement officers are preferred for transporting violent prisoners, fiscal or logistical concerns may lead to the use of private prisoner transport companies. If a government entity chooses to use a private company, regulations should be in place to ensure public safety. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "crime of violence" is defined as in section 924(c)(3) of title 18, United States Code. The term "private prisoner transport company" refers to any entity, other than the United States or a State, that transports individuals committed to the custody of a State for compensation. A "violent prisoner" is defined as an individual in the custody of a State. The term "violent prisoner" refers to an individual in the custody of a State or its subdivisions who has been convicted of a violent crime or is currently facing charges for such offenses. Federal regulation of prisoner transport companies. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant organizations, will establish regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines, including background checks and drug testing for employees. The regulations will include minimum standards for background checks, preemployment drug testing, and training for employees transporting prisoners across state lines. Background checks will disqualify individuals with felony or domestic violence convictions, and drug testing will comply with state laws. Training for employees must not exceed 100 hours of preservice training. Minimum standards for training employees transporting prisoners include up to 100 hours of preservice training covering restraints, searches, use of force, CPR, map reading, and defensive driving. Restrictions on duty hours will also be implemented. The training for employees transporting prisoners includes use of restraints, searches, use of force, CPR, map reading, and defensive driving. Restrictions on duty hours will be implemented, with minimum standards for supervising violent prisoners. Minimum standards for personnel supervising violent prisoners include a requirement of 1 agent for every 6 prisoners, along with employee uniforms with identification badges. Minimum standards for transporting violent prisoners include requirements for employee uniforms with identification badges, brightly colored clothing for prisoners, and restraints such as leg shackles and double-locked handcuffs. Standards for transporting violent prisoners include categories for identifying them with brightly colored clothing, using leg shackles and double-locked handcuffs, and notifying local law enforcement of scheduled stops. Private prisoner transport companies must notify local law enforcement 24 hours in advance of transporting violent prisoners. In case of an escape, immediate notification to law enforcement and the contracting entity is required. Minimum safety standards for violent prisoners must be followed according to Federal and State laws. Private prisoner transport companies must adhere to minimum safety standards for violent prisoners as per Federal and State laws. Regulations under this Act should not impose stricter standards on these companies compared to the United States Marshals Service, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and Immigration. Private prisoner transport companies must comply with minimum safety standards for violent prisoners according to Federal and State laws. Regulations under this Act should not be more stringent for these companies than for the United States Marshals Service, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and Immigration when transporting violent prisoners under similar circumstances, except for subsection (b)(6) requirements. Any person violating regulations under this Act may face a civil penalty up to $10,000 per violation and be responsible for prosecution costs. They must also reimburse any entity that incurred expenses in apprehending an escaped violent prisoner due to the violation of regulations.
